content.title: Hemodialysis
content.summary: Extracorporeal blood purification using diffusion across a semipermeable membrane to remove uremic toxins, excess fluid, and correct electrolyte imbalances in ESRD
key_points: Standard regimen: 3-4 hours, 3 times weekly (in-center or home HD)
Vascular access hierarchy: AV fistula > AV graft > tunneled catheter
Dialysis adequacy measured by Kt/V (target ≥1.2 for thrice-weekly HD)
Complications: Hypotension (most common), muscle cramps, access complications, dialysis disequilibrium
Dry weight determination is crucial for ultrafiltration goals
Anticoagulation with heparin or citrate prevents clotting in extracorporeal circuit
Long-term HD associated with cardiovascular disease, bone disease, and reduced quality of life
content.statement: Hemodialysis is an extracorporeal blood purification technique using diffusion and convection across a semipermeable membrane to replace kidney function in patients with ESRD or severe AKI.

explanation.intuition: Think of hemodialysis as an external kidney. Blood flows through thousands of tiny hollow fibers in a dialyzer. Waste products diffuse from blood (high concentration) across the membrane into dialysate (low concentration), while excess fluid is removed by pressure-driven ultrafiltration.
explanation.key_insight: Successful hemodialysis depends on three pillars: adequate vascular access (sufficient blood flow), appropriate dialysis prescription (time, frequency, dialyzer size), and proper dry weight assessment (fluid removal without hypotension).
explanation.technical_details: Solute clearance occurs by diffusion (concentration gradient) and convection (solvent drag with ultrafiltration). Small molecules (urea, creatinine) clear efficiently by diffusion; larger molecules (beta-2 microglobulin) require high-flux membranes and convective clearance. Blood flow rates of 350-450 mL/min and dialysate flow of 500-800 mL/min optimize clearance.

definitions_glossary.hemodialysis: Extracorporeal blood purification using diffusion across a semipermeable membrane
definitions_glossary.dialyzer: Artificial kidney containing semipermeable membrane fibers for solute and fluid removal
definitions_glossary.av_fistula: Arteriovenous fistula; surgical connection between artery and vein for vascular access
definitions_glossary.av_graft: Synthetic tube connecting artery and vein when native fistula not possible
definitions_glossary.tunneled_catheter: Central venous catheter for dialysis access; higher infection risk
definitions_glossary.kt_v: Dialysis adequacy measure: K=clearance, t=time, V=volume of distribution; target ≥1.2
definitions_glossary.dry_weight: Patient's weight at optimal euvolemic state after ultrafiltration
definitions_glossary.ultrafiltration: Fluid removal during dialysis by hydrostatic pressure across membrane
definitions_glossary.dialysate: Solution flowing opposite to blood in dialyzer; contains electrolytes and buffer
definitions_glossary.high_flux_membrane: Dialyzer membrane with larger pores allowing middle molecule clearance
definitions_glossary.hemodiafiltration: Combines hemodialysis and hemofiltration for enhanced middle molecule clearance
definitions_glossary.intradialytic_hypotension: Blood pressure drop during dialysis; most common acute complication

pathophysiology.mechanism: Extracorporeal blood purification replacing nephron function through diffusion, convection, and ultrafiltration

dialysis_principles.diffusion: Solute movement from high to low concentration across semipermeable membrane
dialysis_principles.convection: Solute movement with solvent (water) across membrane; solvent drag
dialysis_principles.ultrafiltration: Water removal by hydrostatic pressure gradient across membrane

factors_affecting_clearance: Dialyzer surface area and membrane characteristics

indications_for_initiation.chronic: ESRD (GFR <10-15 mL/min) with uremic symptoms, refractory fluid overload, or electrolyte abnormalities
indications_for_initiation.acute: AKI with AEIOU criteria - Acidosis, Electrolytes (hyperK), Intoxication, Overload, Uremia

av_fistula.advantages: Lowest infection rate, best longevity, highest flow rates
av_fistula.complications: Steal syndrome, high-output heart failure, aneurysm

av_graft.complications: Higher thrombosis and infection rates than fistula

tunneled_catheter.use: Bridge to permanent access, when AVF/AVG not possible
tunneled_catheter.complications: Highest infection rate, central venous stenosis, inadequate flow

adequacy_assessment.kt_v: Target ≥1.2 for thrice-weekly HD; ≥1.8 for twice-weekly
adequacy_assessment.clinical_assessment: Symptom control, nutrition, blood pressure, quality of life

modalities.in_center_hd: Standard 3-4 hours, 3 times weekly at dialysis facility
modalities.home_hd: Patient-administered; allows more frequent or longer treatments
modalities.nocturnal_hd: 6-8 hours overnight; better solute clearance and fluid removal
modalities.short_daily_hd: 5-6 days/week for shorter sessions; improved BP and phosphorus control

prescription_components.time: 3-4 hours standard; longer for large patients or high UF needs
prescription_components.frequency: 3 times weekly standard; more frequent associated with better outcomes
prescription_components.dialyzer: High-flux membrane preferred; surface area 1.5-2.5 m²
prescription_components.dialysate: K+ 2-3 mEq/L, Ca²+ 2.5-3.5 mEq/L, bicarbonate buffer
prescription_components.ultrafiltration: Goal based on dry weight; rate <13 mL/kg/hr reduces hypotension risk

anticoagulation.heparin_free: Saline flushes for high bleeding risk
anticoagulation.citrate_regional: For patients with HIT or active bleeding

complication_management.hypotension: Reduce UF rate, trendelenburg, saline bolus, cool dialysate
complication_management.cramps: Saline bolus, reassess dry weight, quinine (use cautiously)
complication_management.access_thrombosis: Thrombolysis or thrombectomy; assess for underlying stenosis
complication_management.dialysis_disequilibrium: Slower/shorter initial sessions in new starts

skos.definition: Extracorporeal blood purification using diffusion and convection across a semipermeable membrane to remove uremic toxins and excess fluid

subcodes: Z49.31 - Encounter for adequacy testing for hemodialysis

learning_objectives: Explain principles of hemodialysis (diffusion, convection, ultrafiltration)
Compare vascular access options and their advantages/complications
Calculate and interpret Kt/V for dialysis adequacy
Recognize and manage acute intradialytic complications
clinical_pearls: AV fistula is the gold standard access - plan 6 months ahead for maturation
Kt/V ≥1.2 is minimum for thrice-weekly HD; more frequent HD allows lower target
Intradialytic hypotension is most common complication; UF rate >13 mL/kg/hr increases risk
Dialysis disequilibrium can occur in new starts - use shorter, slower sessions initially
Central catheters have 10x higher infection rate than fistulas
High-flux dialyzers clear beta-2 microglobulin better, reducing dialysis-related amyloidosis
Cool dialysate (35.5°C) reduces hypotension by preventing vasodilation
Missed dialysis sessions dramatically increase mortality risk

common_questions: Patient starting dialysis in 6 months - what access should be placed now?
